awd_titl_txt: Dissecting contribution of Cas9-induced DNA unwinding to specificity in gene editing
awd_abstract_narration:
The groundbreaking 2013 discovery that CRISPR-Cas9 can be programmed to efficiently edit genomes in complex organisms sparked a revolution in genetic engineering that is still rapidly unfolding. This project will test a hypothesis on how CRISPR-Cas9 discriminates between correct vs. incorrect DNA targets, and advance the capability of a biophysical technique known as site-directed spin labeling to the level of interrogating biomolecules one at a time under physiological conditions. The research is expected to yield mechanistic understanding that will aid further development of genome editing tools, and to advance technology that can benefit the broader scientific community. The project will also contribute to training of the STEM workforce via research engagement and curriculum development at both graduate and undergraduate levels, and will support outreach to the public on issues related to genome editing that have profound societal impacts.

Clustered-Regularly-Interspaced-Short-Palindromic-Repeats (CRISPR) and CRISPR-associated (Cas) proteins provide adaptive immunity for bacteria and archaea. In type II CRISPR, a single Cas9 protein is activated by small RNA(s) to cleave DNA duplexes at specific sites. A key step in Cas9 target acquisition is unwinding of the DNA duplex to form a stable R-loop structure in which the RNA guide-segment is base-paired with the target-strand of the DNA protospacer. Studies have established a sequential unwinding model for Cas9 target acquisition, and these mechanistic insights have been instrumental in driving developments of CRISPR-based technology. However, understanding of mechanisms of Cas9 function is far from complete. In this project, Aim 1 will map the boundary of Cas9-induced DNA unwinding in bulk solution using a combination of spin-labeling and fluorescence spectroscopy; Aim 2 will examine the interdependency between Cas9 target cleavage and variations in the boundary of DNA unwinding; and Aim 3 will develop spin-labeling methods for investigating Cas9-induced DNA unwinding at the level of single molecules. The work will advance fundamental understanding of CRISPR-Cas9 function by testing a "two-state equilibrium" hypothesis on target discrimination, and will yield new biophysical techniques that broadly impact studies on nucleic acids and protein-nucleic acid complexes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
CRISPR-Cas (clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat − CRISPR-associated proteins) is an RNA-guided adaptive immune system widespread in bacteria and archaea. Adaptations of CRISPR-Cas systems have enabled facile manipulation of genomes in a wide range of organisms, leading to a revolution in genome engineering that is still rapidly advancing. Cas9, a type II CRISPR effector protein, is the most widely used Cas-protein in genome engineering. However, off-target effects remain a major obstacle in CRISPR-Cas9 applications, and in-depth mechanistic understanding of Cas9 target discrimination has been, and continue to be, the foundation for improving Cas9 specificity. In this project, we applied a unique biophysical technique, site-directed spin labeling, in conjunction with fluorescence spectroscopy and enzyme kinetics analysis, to investigate mechanisms of target DNA discrimination used by CRISPR-Cas9. In parallel, we further developed site-directed spin labeling methods for investigating large protein-nucleic acid complexes in bulk solutions and at the single-molecule level.

Intellectual Merit: As of the date of this report, this grant has supported work reported in eight published manuscripts and one book chapter, with two additional manuscripts in preparation. Our major achievements and their impacts include:

  • We uncovered that Cas9 effectors containing truncated RNA guides (i.e., those shorter than the normal length of 20-nucleotide) induce partial unwinding of target DNA at the PAM-distal segment beyond the RNA/DNA hybrid pairing. Physical property of “peripheral” DNA sequences beyond the RNA/DNA hybrid, specifically the intrinsic DNA duplex stability, modulates the degree of PAM-distal unwinding, thus tuning the transition state of the DNA cleavage reaction with Cas9 effectors containing truncated guides. This results in sequence dependent cleavage rates that demonstrate target discrimination. The finding unveils a fresh perspective that intimately connects intrinsic DNA physical properties with Cas9 target discrimination, and provides mechanistic insights for further developing strategies that use RNA guide truncation to enhance Cas9 specificity.
  • We advanced spin-labeling methodologies with contributions including: (i) first detection of Electron Paramagnetic Resonance spectrum of single spin-labeled DNA duplex; (ii) establishing the use of natural base-pairs for site-specific labeling of large RNA molecules; and (iii) validating a modeling tool for predicting inter-label distances in protein-nucleic acid complexes. In particular, the work on single spin-labeled DNA achieves a 10-order enhancement in sensitivity as compared to convention bulk measurements that require around 10-billion spins. With the measurements carrying in aqueous solutions at ambient temperature, the work advances the field by demonstrating single spin measurements beyond the confine of solid-phase samples, thus establishing a foundation for single-molecule magnetic resonance investigation of structure and dynamics of biomolecules in their native environments.

Broader Impacts: Our work on advancing mechanistic understanding of Cas9 and developing spin-labeling tools impacts a broad spectrum of scientific disciplines, ranging from genome engineering to understanding protein-nucleic acid interaction and expanding biophysical methodologies for investigating the fundamental structure-dynamics-function relationship governing biological processes. The grant has enabled STEM work force development by training postdoctoral fellows and students with a diverse background, and by supporting the PI’s efforts on integrating research into undergraduate and graduate curriculum. The grant has also supported PI’s service, including work with the Internal EPR Society, which benefits the broader community.
